Section 7 Overview

Section 7 of the U.S. Endangered Species Act (ESA) is often considered the most important section of the law. Any federal agency whose actions may affect an ESA-listed species are required to consult with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and/or the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) to ensure the action does not jeopardize the species’ existence or adversely modify or destroy its critical habitat. A federal action could mean a number of things, such as:

  • issuing a permit to dredge or fill a wetland (a Clean Water Act 404 permit);
  • funding a highway project; or
  • carrying out an activity, such as prescribed burns on a National Forest.

The reach and strength of section 7 means it is the focus of many arguments about the ESA. Despite decades of argument, no one had checked to see what the data had to say about how the section has been implemented. In 2015, we published the first complete analysis of section 7 consultations done by FWS in the ESA’s 42-year history (Malcom and Li, 2015). That analysis showed that common perceptions of how the section is implemented are often wrong.

This web application provides access to the entire dataset analyzed by Malcom and Li, plus data updates provided by FWS since the publication."
